awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Mapping the Chemical Reactivity of Metal Oxide Photocatalysts by Correlative Single-Molecule Fluorescence and Electron Microscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanocrystal photocatalysts are tiny, synthetic crystals that use light to accelerate chemical reactions. Photocatalysts that make fuels, such as methane, using only carbon dioxide, water and sunlight would have significant benefit to society. However, developing photocatalysts capable of sunlight-to-fuel conversion is a challenging problem that requires a fundamental understanding of the chemical reactions taking place on the nanocrystal surface. With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Professor Sadtler at Washington University in St. Louis is developing microscopy methods to watch individual, light-driven reactions as they occur on single nanocrystal photocatalysts. Together, Professor Sadtler and his students are gaining new insights into why some atomic sites on the surface of nanocrystals are particularly active for catalysis. Professor Sadtler is also infusing his research into education. He is developing new courses that use atomic structure and chemical bonding as a basis to teach the frontiers of chemistry and materials science, as well as working with high school teachers and students in the St. Louis area.

Metal oxide semiconductor nanocrystals with tunable stoichiometry are promising photocatalysts to produce liquid fuels through solar water splitting, partial methane oxidation, and the reduction of carbon dioxide. However, the contribution of specific structural and morphological features among individual catalyst particles to their ensemble activity is not well understood because each particle is different and possesses a variety of potential reaction sites. This project uses super-resolution fluorescence microscopy and redox-active fluorogenic probes to monitor photoinduced charge-transfer events on individual metal oxide nanocrystals with nanoscale spatial resolution. Correlation of the reactivity maps with the atomic resolution of scanning transmission electron microscopy performed on the same particles reveals how the distribution of oxygen vacancies in individual particles affects their reactivity. To further develop structure-activity relationships in metal oxide photocatalysts, the single-molecule, single-particle data are compared to measurements of bulk photocatalytic activity for methane oxidation and carbon dioxide reduction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Semiconductor nanocrystals are tiny particles that harvest energy from sunlight. Through a process known as photocatalysis, they can produce liquid fuels and other useful chemicals for energy storage and environmental remediation. For example, semiconductor nanocrystals can split water molecules to make hydrogen fuel and oxygen in a green process that does not emit any greenhouse gases. Currently, the reported efficiencies of semiconductor nanocrystals for photocatalytic water splitting are still far lower than what is needed to replace fossil fuels as the world’s primary source of energy. To improve the efficiency by which semiconductor nanocrystals generate chemical fuels from sunlight, a better scientific understanding is needed for how light-driven chemical reactions take place on their surface. However, a major challenge in developing structure/activity relationships for these materials is that semiconductor nanocrystals exhibit particle-to-particle variations that affect their activity and stability for photocatalysis, such as differences in size, shape, and surface structure, even for particles synthesized within the same batch. Such heterogeneity makes it difficult to identify the chemical structure of surface sites responsible for catalytic reactions; this critical information is averaged over when measurements of activity are made large numbers of particles.

Intellectual merit: Through the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Sadtler at Washington University in St. Louis developed new chemical insights into how the surface structure of semiconductor nanocrystals mediate their photocatalytic activity and stability. To address the challenges above, Prof. Sadtler and his students used fluorescence microscopy to visualize individual, light-driven reactions as they take place on the surface of individual semiconductor nanocrystals. By comparing videos obtained by single-molecule fluorescence microscopy to more conventional methods of catalyst characterization, they elucidated the chemical traits that make certain atomic sites on the surface of a nanocrystal more active for photocatalysis than other sites. For example, a crystal defect known as an oxygen vacancy (i.e., the absence of an oxygen atom at a site where it would normally occur in the crystal) has been shown to enhance the photocatalytic activity of a variety of different compositions of metal oxide semiconductor nanocrystals. However, the amount and distribution of oxygen vacancies in a batch of nanocrystals will vary from particle to particle, which has led to competing mechanisms proposed for how this defect enhances activity. Through single-molecule fluorescence imaging, Prof. Sadtler and students revealed that it is clusters of oxygen vacancies rather than isolated defect sites that produce high photocatalytic activity in semiconductor nanowires composed of tungsten oxide. Furthermore, the distribution of oxygen vacancies is not uniform along the length of the nanowires, which leads to nanoscale “hot spots” or regions of high activity interspersed with inactive regions. For another type of semiconductor photocatalyst composed of bismuth oxybromide nanoplates, low to moderate concentrations of oxygen vacancies increase the amount of visible light that is absorbed by the nanocrystals, which enhances their ability to use light energy to mediate chemical reactions. However, when the concentration of oxygen vacancies is too high, these defects decrease activity by promoting the relaxation of electrons that are needed to induce the photocatalytic reaction. Sadtler and students also discovered that the concentration of defects varies from particle to particle which leads to a wide variation in their relative activity for the light-driven oxidation of water, an important reaction in the generation of hydrogen fuel from sunlight. The impact of these efforts is to inform the design of semiconductor photocatalysts that can produce useful chemicals from sunlight. While the presence of oxygen vacancies can increase the activity of many semiconductor photocatalysts, their distribution should be uniform and their concentration stable to maintain high activity.

Broader impacts: Support from this project provided research and educational opportunities for 9 graduate students, 7 undergraduate students, 3 high-school teachers, and 16 high-school students. The graduate and undergraduate students gained skills in nanomaterial synthesis, structural, optical, and electrochemical characterization of semiconductors, catalysis, and fluorescence microscopy. To integrate research and education, Prof. Sadtler developed new learning modules for both the courses he teaches at Washington University and for high-school students in outreach activities to use atomic structure and chemical bonding as a basis to teach the frontiers of chemistry and materials science. Teacher–research partnerships provided professional development for three high-school teachers by introducing current research in solid-state chemistry, fluorescence microscopy, nanoscience, electrochemistry, and catalysis. Prof. Sadtler and graduate student participants met with high-school students at the teacher’s school, where they introduced computer modeling software to visualize and understand the three-dimensional structure and properties of crystalline solids. Graduate students gave presentations on their research projects and how fundamental research on controlling the structure and properties of crystalline materials can provide solutions to pressing problems in energy and the environment.
